titleStmt.title: Huon d'Auvergne, Kupferstichkabinett 78 D 8 (olim Hamilton 337) Annotations

div.note: MS: une,(final -e is expunctuated)
queus MS: quilens with a dot under each letter, "il" i."
All text that is written above the line in the original is enclosed in parentheses in this transcription.
This line is problematic for sense; the Turin version is also unclear.
MS: revser
MS: nolōs This is an interesting slip: non added to a form of voloir.
ia belist. This is a hapax. Elsewhere in the text, we find l'abelist, e.g., 4169, 6321, etc.
There is a "+" in the right margin in light brown ink, perhas inserted by a nineteenth-century reader.
Cf. Entrée d'Espagne, gaumenter (TL gaimenter)
MS missing an abbreviation mark here in acoplir; cf. Vv. 1271, 1282, etc.
The MS is difficult to read: 'r'of complira is unclear.
pregant: the "g" has an unusual form; it looks more like a "y"

MS: empial. Cf. vv. 47, 73, 373, etc., where we see emp[er]ial. However, see empir in the Prise de Pampelune (v. 4970) and the many other variants. As one of the most frequent words in epic vocabulary, it is greatly varied in rhyme. Furthermore, in Italian, "empio" means "irreligioso, sacrilego, profanatore" and "spietato, crudele" (Zingarelli) so while there is the hint of emperor, there is also the sense of merciless, sacrilegious ruler.
MS:abosdivoir. Cf. Entrée d'Espagne bosdeor; Guerra d'Attila bosder, bosdeor, bosdera, bosdie, etc.
MS:confortas ɾoe
Tutore: cf. www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/tuttora_(Enciclopedia-Dantesca)/. Typical of Old Italian, found in Dante, the Fiore, etc. Consulted Nov. 26, 2016.
MS: monreç
Note the Italianate construction of definite article + possessive.
hair: this could be haïr, anger, but we are interpreting it as "air" to go with the Turin reading and also the sense here: out the window and into the air, the sky.

la is almost unreadable in the manuscript. It is unclear whether this was intentional or not on the part of the scribe or was done later; it seems to be something painted over those letters, but similar to a spot on the left side of the page of a chocolate or cafeaulait color.
Catchword at the bottom of the page, almost entirely washed out:si
There are three other forms (aflicions twice, aflicion once), all in rhyme position. Therefore I here presume aflicion as the base form, here elided with the preposition a.

Between lines 1249 and 1250 in column 9va, running into the right margin is a line with an "x"; also at the bottom of column 9va, there is a line with a corresponding "x" in the left margin. Since the column is one line too long in comparison to the other, and normally the columns are equal, this final line (1264) is clearly to be moved to the position between 1249 and 1250.

Sir désigne la ville de Tyr, puisque les tissus d'Orient étaient réputés et [...] l'on indique volentiers une ville d'Orient comme lieu d'où provient un tissu précieux. ("Sir" refers to the city Tyre, since oriental fabrics were famous and a famous city of the East is frequently used as a source for a valuable fabric (trans. LZM)).
MS:ma[n]dana, however it seems most likely to be an error for "via[n]da na"; cf. line 6181 viande n'a.
MS: q eloiaute; an nseems to be elided, which would have read: Q'en loiauté.

The rhyme here is normally a diphthongue but the simple past of oïr is bisyllabic, so the editor must choose between the rhyme spellings or the usual representation of the simple past of this verb. See also 8160, 11274.
In the rhyme position, the verb "savoir" takes this unusual form.
MS: riponse; cf. forms of reponser (v. 2505, 2690, etc.).
MS: constatinople
MS: afie đs (crossed 'd' and long 's' above the line between 'a' and 'f').
trainé here is the infinitive, missing the final -r ; this is how T understood the line. Alternatively it could be v'oit trainé, "the kings had there dragged before them"

The MS is damaged at this point and extremely difficult to read. T: morty zasere al sabione [dead men lying on the sand]. If the reading here were similar, it might be hon veit sor ce gravois; but the two are not always parallel. Gravoy appears appears five times, gravois once, in this text, meaning "sand" or "gravel" in some way (path, etc.) in this MS.

The beginning of this column is faded in parts, though the outlines of strokes are clear. For multiple minims, there can always be doubts, but in searching other F-I texts there are no forms of sui- for the verb "to follow," whereas there are 68 forms of siv- attested in FIOLA. RIALFrI however, offers both. In this text there are 3 other forms with siv-, one seut, but none with sui- unless the minims are reconstrued in those appearances as well, thus siveç here, though the connectors are in fact suiveç.
MS: giat
MS: nos
The word et seems out of place here; emend to e?

Between les and afi at the end of the line is a hole in the MS; afi seems to be written deliberately after it; there does not seem to be any letter missing. J.-C. Vallecalle suggests that it might have been an a there [possibly scraped off?], making the line read Posible çonse il fust, bien le sai a fi, that is, "This [Huon's mission in Hell] would be possible, I know certainly (... if Hell were built on earth)."
gieter may have been the original reading of the text, for "how to shoot a bow".
MS seems to be missing the abbreviation for n: m'acontent; cf. V. 747
T 2126: Se p[er] devin miraclo non m'avene
These 6 lines are very difficult to read due to the ink being worn off. Ultraviolet does not help much.
aquitier: there are 16 forms beginning with aquit- (and one other following d') compared to 9 that are clearly quit-, so we have divided those following d as beginning with the vowel.
MS: resont with a caret below to insert a tiny p written above the line.
MS: le nay ster
Note that n and u are frequently very similar in the MS. Ansi is perhaps also possible or intended.
MS: Bout
âbandon = "a abandon"
Veriteç appears twice (5504, 11099) and veritere once (6308) to one verté (8736), so we resolve here as we do.

aveit a bone foyseems to be a MS error with either an extraa(he had good faith or he went in good faith) or perhaps a u for an n (aneit as some form of "andare"), though there is no such form listed in RIALFrI for other Franco-Italian texts.
Final letter is hard to distinguish; could be os.
The phrase sans poy appears to be equivalent to "sans plus"; could it be an Italianism, with palatalization of the consonant + l (cf. Modern Italian "più")?
We believe thatsavra is like the use of Modern Standard Italian "sapere," "to taste": it seems (it tastes) like...
T: grande e derupossa p[er]ché ponto son li agradise

Brown ink through theor of d[e]morr[re]. mal has a line above it; it is not the standard abbreviation for r or vowel + r, and there are no other abbreviations with l, so its resolution is not immediately evident.
MS: sta[n]cht
T: Quando el vede avrire la gola ch'el vede el fogo apredre; B seems to be understanding vait for both verbs, baër and esprenda[n]t
T has understood this differently: "I praise [him] willingly (with good heart)." This could also be the meaning here, in which case the preceding line would end with a comma instead of a semicolon.
MS lö tēptz. This seems to be an unusual case of assonance alone, not rhyme.
After tost, scratched out letter in the MS.
There is a letter scratched out after il before atant. This folio in general has many corrections.
li jorner: This expression can mean "journey" or "day" in Old French. In Italian, it would mean "day." Difficult to say which is intended here.
ge inserted above the line.

Note the use of n here for "nous" (ne before vowel) object form. This is typical of early Italian texts. See Rohlfs, Morfologia, paragraph 460. This is a legal formula meaning in the presence of witnesses.
MS: ci ņait. Though the n is expunctuated, it seems to be necessary for the meaning; see translation.
MS: pelle. p with a line above is always p[re] and thus is so transcribed here.
Abbreviation line very light in the MS.
MS: vait.seems to be a form of "valoir"
MS: alieç: CF T-L 278-279 alegier, "to be eased, lightened"; Folco di Candia> V19, l. 1581.
Thse laisse initial here has a face sketched into it.
We interpret aseori as from *asseoir, "to rest, stop on a trip."
quoy = coi = "tranquille," T-L "still"; s'ora derives from orer "anwünschen" = "wish"
dela : "over there," not "by there," so one word. There are many appearances of this construction in rhyme position.
MS mont le sen: le expunctuated
segure: DELI scure, segure before 1292, derives from SECŪRE(M), Latin
Funny face drawn into the capital for this laisse, as for many in this section of the MS.
This version differs from Turin where it is the serpent that cries out.

Or va pur a giter. This is one case where the French and Italian constructions differ but the meaning is approximately the same: "by rolling he was going to move it" and "by rolling he was going to toss it."

For this section, cf. Le roman d'Alexandre, Branche III, laisses 160-162, part of the "Dangerous Valley" where Alexander confronts a demon in order to leave. (Harf-Lancner trans. of E. C. Armstrong, pp. 470-477).
Here Huon seems to address the figure-- or the ladies and the figure-- aloud.
The MS seems to be missing the abbreviation for an "r" here: archiere, "archer," as in vv. 1710, 9216, 11662, 1204 archiers
This might be a reference to Dante's hell: those inside the walls of Hell (Canto 10) cannot see the present and see the future only dimly (10.94-105).
MS: oi ge, with ge expunctuated, the g with a dot above, the e with dot both above and below.
MS: lemme
MS: nōs avōs; ; note the use of the first person plural as subject.
MS: geste beste
Turin 3704: quando y[n] mia vita tanto ben fato averò
si seiron could also read s'iseiron, "they went out"; there are no similar forms for "to sit," and Turin has them sitting down, "putting" themselves at the table.
alor could also read a lor, "to them." Cf. T 3801 a le soue done
MS: vons
el inserted above the line
T: de zorno y[n] zorno quanty y[n] naserano; it would seem that the Italian writer did not understand the text.
MS: fable pece home
This is Psalm 133, verses 1-2; Dante also quotes it in his Monarchia, Book 1.
T: "con più marinary chi menauna grosa nava appears at this point.
te[re]rre: This is unusual, perhaps the adding of an unnecessary abbreviation mark when the full word is already present.

Cf. Matthew 7.14, "For the gate is narrow and the way is hard, that leads to life, and those who find it are few." Vulgate: "Quam angusta porta, et arcta via est, que ducit ad vitam: et pauci sunt qui inveniunt eam!" If we were to transcribe Stroite ert la voie qui no l'atient a tant it would reflect an Italianate structure with a tanti: "Stretta è la via che non l'ottiene a tanti" or "non la tiene a tanti"– "that not many can hold to it' "or "that not many can succeed at it"
This is a complicated passage, with non-standard forms: aroman in particular poses a riddle.
The first hemistich of this line seems to be a repeat of 4501 above; in Turin, however, the two also repeat. so it is clearly part of the tradition.

Istrent, istront appear a number of times in this text; aman this once, but also in Attila, where it is defined as "subito" IX, 254. T clearly did not understand: li stre[n]ze la man, "he shook his hand."
MS : adonet; the Ie cross-stroke is very light but present. Since the scribe is in general very careful expunctuating errors and otherwise correcting, this seems to be a true error and we here emend.
Asié comes from aasier (TL), "to reassure."

The end of the line could also be interpreted fai ces demostreison, but since Turin reads "fazy demostranza" we construe it this way. There are no other forms faicés; faige and faigés are related to "fatigué," but there are three faice tokens from "to do/to make."

The previous line, at the end of folio 32V, ends with the catchwords A Ynide which do not then begin the next folio or signature. There is a space in the MS after arcives that seems to be scraped; something is visible around the edges. With ultraviolet, one can almost see "q" and "e", and maybe something above the line too, qe with u above the line? Or just a bit of chalk solution or whatever they used.Thus we give this as an emendation.
MS: plais

The reading Tholomé here is problematic, since Tholomeus has not been designated head of the band of ambassadors or otherwise much discussed until now. The MS T reads "Servire debe esere tal sire [et] de grande [et] de menore," in line 4745; perhaps the original here was "tal ome" (such a man), referring to the king? The first column of this folio in fact in line four (this is line 3 of column two) is line 4707 where "Tholomeu" appears.
The end of this line and the next are missing in the MS.
MS: selong
MS: peçe = OF "pieça"
MS: bien (sic!)
Langlois lists Teris as Lord of Vermandois (p. 668).
This line is incomplete in the MS. These laisses are not in B, so there can be no reconstruction from that text.
MS: un êve since êve is always feminine in this text= "une eve"
MS: pote[r] for porter.
Something is clearly missing in this line, perhaps de [servir] vos? Cf. T, "de complire la vostra volontady" (4782)

This line is incomplete in the MS. In MS T, v. 4820 reads "Ay, cristianità, como ay tuo onore p[er]duto!" There is a letter after m that was removed, it looks like another m; the rest of the letters are bled through from the back.

This line is incomplete in the MS. In MS T, v. 4851 reads "Dona," dize Berardo, "che loro lasate-ly y[n]trare". There is clearly a difficulty with this line, though the general idea is clear: "Lady," said Berardo,"may you allow them to enter."
MS: jambaseors
MS: colleste
Unusual abbreviation form: empeos with a sign over "e" and "o-"; perhaps a two-part sign?
MS serees: the second 'e' has a tiny dot below and a bigger one above; not clear though if it should be expunctuated. We have here.
MS T reads: "vuy avite p[er] vuy tramiso, [et] zò e my y[n]seme siemo." Ensoine = "crazy, insane"?
cu[n]: the final "n" here is the "vertical m" found in Latin texts. Cf. CPLEDTM, Fasc. 1, p. 28.
We understand strine related to the verb "stringere."
MS: ētase
MS: avon. MS T reads, "che avante m'averoy lo coro fenduto / e l'anyma de my del tuto avere p[er]duta" [for before I would have my heart split, and my soul completely lost ...]
T: "chi non fosse y[n] vergogna de l'apele" [who is not ashamed to call him]
Trasumanar: cf. Dante Par. I, 70. This must be one of its earliest usages after Dante (DELI: before 1321, Dante, first use).
MS: baroine. The second and third strokes are clearly linked at the top and the first and second at the bottom.

MS: sa aubçēt ("b" also has a titulus over it). We emend here in part because of syllable count and in part because of sense: "sa aubercent" does not make sense: it is either two verbs together or a singular possessive pronoun plus plural verb.
reïre: from the prefix RE- + ire

Should this be "Canace" from Ovid's Heroides 11, where she committed incest with Macareus, her brother, and her father Aeolus sent her a sword to kill herself (and exposed the baby)? In 1542 it was made into a play by Sperone Speroni, so was clearly known in Italy in the sixteenth century. For the English translation, see http://www.poetryintranslation.com/PITBR/Latin/Heroides8-15.php#anchor_Toc524696648.
MS appears to read niiēs

The forms here are unlike others we have seen; and these lines are omitted from the T MS. We have interpreted sorer as "suer" and scaulir as "echauffer" through an Italianate "caldo" since Ital "scaldare" = to burn, though one might expect opposite expressions. The T text (in a different order) does mention the "fire of love," v. 5346, "Lo feu d'amore sovente li fate sentire ."
MS: pālam
MS: dolonor
MS: empëo, where the descender of the "p" is also crossed.
MS: susnel
This and next three lines a puzzle. There seems to be a series of comparisons with references to fables; the lines are not present in T.
The identity of "Ulliendre" is unclear; there is no record of the name in that form in Classical or medieval literature. The references are missing from the T MS.

For Porus, see Roman d'Alexandre, Branche 3, laisses 30-240. The meaning and derivation of desgrendre are unclear. Perhaps "sgrenre" cf. genero = gendre; tenero = tendre etc."to seed a fruit/remove bits from cob; recite the rosary; eat with glee" Disticha catonis Catonis distichorum 30: Quae culpare soles, ea tu ne feceris ipse, Turpe est doctori, cum culpa redarguit ipsum. [Those things you are accustomed to blame do not do yourself; It is bad for a wise man when his own guilt comes back (to haunt him)]. Text and translation, Jim Marchand. MS: mebruç MS: dorit baster: = Italian "bastare" [to be enough, to suffice]; attested 1253, DELI (unknown origin; no attestation in OF, TL) Avist: there are three tokens with this sequence of letters: 5601 and 7579 in addition to this line. In each case it is a form of the verb "to have," interpreted also by Mainone as avist (Formenlehre 24), similar to the forms in Entrée d'Espagne, Attila, V4, etc. As Veillard and Guyotjeannin's Conseils suggest, the alternation between "u" and "v" (avit and avait appear, as do aüst and aüstes, aüsés) suggests an interpretation with "v" (Fasc. I, 25). MS: maçerie: the letter "l" seems to have been corrected in "r" (for "Margery"). MS: nuit demi .pl'. with a caret between nuit and demi Blank folio, Recto and Verso, follows. plus mes: "plus mieux" MS: son son signor Line incomplete; T 5987 "charegò-le per vero lo francho conte" MS: over it plu there is an ink smear. For MS Ala a Agollant; reference to Aspremont Golir: an Italian-based form; cf. Guerra d'Attila, goloient; TLIO goliare, "desiderare." MS: (t) is inserted above line with a caret under the line before the s is underpunctuated at end of the word. S'aregone: Cf. T, line 6108 "s'araduna," to meet; we are interpreting "aregone" as related to aringo TLIO , "a place for meeting, a meeting" and extrapolate the verb as "to meet" fanos written as one word in the manuscript, as usual for object pronouns following the imperative. astu written as one word in the manuscript, as usual for subject following the verb in question. engaigne: trickery, cunning, wiliness Mestre could be understood as a feminine plural here, in which case the comparison would be with other female necromancers. The line in general is tricky because the verb seems singular (soit) but tant would indicate a plural. Stengel: efforç par... Cf. the Roman d'Alexandre, bk. 3. Cf. the Roman d'Alexandre, for Porus. Alexandre, l. 3189 li lusage: this seems to be a case of "concretion of the article": that is, lusage is a plural noun for "habits" or "customs." Cf. Rohlfs ¶341, l. 3189 (e): written above the line, very light, no caret below (not visible in the microfilm). DELI: vanagloriarsi "vantarsi, essere pieno di sé," 13th century. MS: Mes e non: ..: expunctuated 'e' after the first word. Matthew 27, 46; Mark 5, 34. Note the word order: le plus + noun + adjective Compare the illumination at the bottom of this page. MS: l'asist. This does not make sense, since the queen approaches him then speaks to him. Cf. Turin line 6448 "dapresso luy s'aseta e possa li rasona"; it can be a banal error of misreading a written text to confuse "l" and the long "s" See Dante, Inf. 5, 112-122, for the joy to sadness trope, here reversed. (qe) inserted above the line with caret below, but very light with tiny letters, not visible in microfilm. Sections of these three lines of the MS are here practically unreadable since somewhat rubbed off; as the middle of the section, the beginning of this line in particular is difficult to distinguish. Whether it is vos or ves cannot be determined. peçé traitor: this could peçe traïtor, "worst traitor"; we have followed Turin's usage of "pechà traditor"; had it been "worst" Turin would have read "peçor" or something similar rather than "pecha" from Latin PECCATU(M). See first (left) part of the illumination below, where he holds a rock in his hand while he kneels in the garden. Roman d'Alexandre, Branche 4, 8-33 (Harf-Larcner 752-83). See the second (right) part of the illumination below, with fires, three angels (one with an open book) and devils coming out of the house on the right. MS: figurablemēt; this seems to be a scribal error, mistaking the initial s for f, and combining "figura" and "segura" with another word, perhaps "ensemble"; cf. T "che a l'ensire no[n] podè ben asegurare" (from "afegurare"). MS: por expunctuated after moy; there is also a scratch through the middle of the word, cutting each letter in half. End of Stengel, "Keuschheitsprobe" (his line 7147). Begin Stengel, "Suche" (his line 7148). FEW: talevas, "bouclier en bois"; cf. Roman d'Alexandre "talavat/z" (RIALFrI, 22.XII.2017), from *TALAPACIUM (https://apps.atilf.fr/lecteurFEW/lire/131/35) (t): inserted above the line, with a dim caret below. c(h)ar: very light insert, with no caret below. See illumination below; on left, ship with line tied to horse; on right, Huon fighting off the birds. Lots of blood, some birds in air, some on ground, and flock coming toward him. Cf. Roman d'Alexander again, for attacks near a pond (Branche 3, laisses 64-85) that include griffons that carry away horses (3, 66; Harf-Lancner pp. 368-87, esp. 370-71). (l)aris: again, very light insertion above the line and no caret. This was probably a correction from a saut de même au même: the preceding al ends with an l so the writer realized afterward the missing l. Possibly s'ant desis; see translation for the alternate meanings. For the second hemistich here, see v. 7135, that ends in the same way; this line might be a scribal saut. See translation. The initial letter of quuens is capitalized, which is unusual for this MS. avit: If read aiut, then the meaning would differ: "Well he helped him so that the horse is not hurt." This section is difficult to parse. We decided to follow Turin, though there are other possibilities (see translation). The division between downstrokes in the MS is unreliable: p[er]cuit/p[er]ciut are both possible. There is a scraped section of MS before t[ro]va, long enough for one letter. It too has the appearance of liquid correction fluid in the MS. If roy refers to God, then it should be capitalized, but it is not clear here whether the poem refers to Charles or to God. Note the unusual abbreviation (for this MS) above sorpagne. Stengel: tue e... MS: maroisas 7279 above. T: "De le prede "(line 6965); cf. T:"Li gra[n] predon" (6963, cf. 7279 here) The scribe seems to have been distracted and miscopied. MS: q vif((q with line over top, normally "que) rocheit: cf TL recet See illumination below: merpeople, male and female. Possible source: there are a number of similar monsters in the Roman d'Alexandre, III, 164 (for mermaids); for men in two parts above the navel, III, 181, etc. As Meregazzi says ("Ugo" 19), the Roman d'Alexandre cites "li Otifal" (p. 319, l. 19, ed. Michelant), so we have divided this into Roman d'Alexandre cites "li Otifal" (p. 319, l. 19, ed. Michelant), so we have divided this into L'Ocifal. However, Harf-Larcner uses "Liotifal" (III, 2452) for "Ichtyophages"; grammatically, an article seems to be necessary in both the Alexandre and here. si at end of line with a dot before it; in the line, a caret below with the same dot to indicate point of insertion. Stengel: abescuç See illumination below with rendering of the creatures. Au pré: nowhere does aupré appear, whereas pré and aprés do appear. Furthermore, here the text makes a point of saying that Huon has just come down the mountain. T: quando un tal remore è al pra venuto (l. 7037). Illumination in fact shows creatures first standing by water then falling from sky amid flames and light. Stengel: vive force (but 1st letter higher, last r); cf. T: Per liura forza, line 7039. Cf. Dante and Brunetto Latini in Inferno: the seventh circle, those of the violent, includes the violent against nature, the sodomites, who walk under a rain of fire (canto 15). plais written below the line, following the next line with a box around three sides a il is written as one word in the MS ap[re]nonl: one cannot help but wonder if there is perhaps something missing here; lines 7475-93 are problematic; Turin has omitted the equivalent of lines 7492-93 and altered line 7490. a fai(t): MS reads la fair, but the line does not make sense without emendation, and a scribal "t" for "r" is a banal error. The other possibility would have been to follow T 7234: perché l'afare è si grande, como eio vo pur pensando, "because the matter is so important, as I believe," adding the verb "is" after l'afair. See also note in the translation.
The illumination at the bottom of this page is of a city with five towers visible, a figure in red (with head covering) at the top of the first gate on the left, nearest the three visitors who are at the far left. The gate figure holds a book with black dots to represent writing on it. Note that the tower is square, suggesting that "reont" refers to something else. Charere (line 9915) means both "chair" (cattedra in MSI) and "highway" in this text, as confirmed by other Franco-Italian texts. In fact, the gateway is rounded and the human figure is at the highest point. Since this is a scholar with a book, it makes the most sense for him to be in a chair or seat. The portion remaining in the Turin MS (folio 146R) shows a loggia with rounded openings to the left of the illumination, with the three travellers outside to the left. One figure inside (with a fancy headdress) is on a chair with a baldacchino in a polygonal shape (not quite a circle, but circular) above. Since the walls in the Berlin MS illumination reach outside the frame, there is nothing above the figure who is on top of the gate there. It is unclear therefore whether the Turin version is a variation of meaning, but in any case, it is one possible explanation of reont. There are several historical figures by the name Nicomachus to whom this may refer. Aristotle's father and son were both so named; the Nichomachean Ethics, a compendium of Aristotle's notes (or Aristotle's notes plus Nichomachus's comments on them) may have been dedicated to the son. Nicomachus of Gerasa, who lived in the first century AD, was a mathematician about whom little is known. His work on the magical properties of numbers and a manual on harmonics, an early discussion of musical theory and pitch. Various other works of his were lost. Since there are references to necromacy in this section, the second identity seems more likely.(Thanks to AEB for assistance in identifying the name.) T: Un nome scrisse sopra la porta de sussa. Farabus: al-Farabi, a great Arabic philosopher, known as Alpharabius in the West, viewed as the "second master" after Aristotle. He lived in the 9th-10th centuries and was known for scientific (which include mathematical and musical works) and philosophical writings (again, thanks to AEB for identifying the figure). See translation for a delineation of speakers in this exchange." -t of cert very smeared and difficult to distinguish exc. in ms. itself. MS: da sa: Turin, pasate; perhaps from "danser" or "dechacier"; it indicates movement forward; cf. Dante, Inf. 3.51: "ma guarda e passa" -ent of ending, -o changed to e. The line is complete, but something is clearly missing for the sense here; cf. T: Dize lo [con]te a Eneas, chy lo mena [The count asks Aeneas, who leads him]. Br similarly reads Dist li quens Ugues ad Eneas qi lo maine (v. 1117).
'e' above the line with caret below. This could be either "fit il" or "fit, 'il n'est'" without a difference in meaning. 'pure' below the line into the edge of the page. (e) is in the binding. MS 'oscüe' sc[r](i)pture: i above the line as abbreviation. In this manuscript there are two forms: par poy (2 appearances) and por poy (one appearance), but only por appears with val and its derivatives. Mixed lists are not unknown, so I have resolved thus here. MS: cu[m] The abbreviation mark here is in the form of a vertical "z"; cf. Viellard, Conseils, Vol. 1, p. 28, # 11. These are all Saracens from Aspremont: Agolant is the ruler of the Saracens, father of Helmont, and killed by Girard's nephew Claire. Uliens is one of Agolant's judges, an important Saracen in the second half of the poem, killed by Richier, grandson of Duke Berengier. This does not follow the French version of Aspremont; Roland killed Eaumont (=Helmont=Almonte). There is nothing about Helmont sleeping. See laisses 286-7 in Suard's edition. The sleeping recalls the motif of Roland killing Ferragu in the Entrée d'Espagne, where Ferragu took a nap using a rock as a pillow, and Roland was tempted to kill him with a stone (vv. 3535-3555). Stengel here proposes the emendation (homes) after .jj. to follow the plot of Aspremont, where Roland kills Eaumont on the second day of the battle. However, jors seems more appropriate for that reason. Cf. F. Suard, ed., Aspremont: Chanson de geste du XIIe siècle, Champion 2008, vv. 3897-5545. 'canter' has a mark above the 'c', like an apostrophe- meaning unclear, but definitely ink and not a defect in the parchment. T: cercare "Death by chessboard" is a chanson de geste motif: in the Geste Francor, Ogier the Dane kills Charlot, Charlemagne's son, with a chessboard; in Renaut de Montauban, Bertholet has died thus also, and further incidents appear in the Batârd de Bouillon and in Parise la duchesse, but there is no known incident relating to Thibaut killing his brother-in-law Folco in the East. On chess in the Middle Ages and its uses, see Jenny Adams, Power Play: The Literature and Politics of Chess in the Late Middle Ages, U of Penn P, 2006; Nicholas Perkins, ed., Medieval Romance and Medieval Culture, D. S. Brewer, 2015. An Italian novella, in fact, insists on Thibaut's family relationship to Guillaume through Folco (married to Anfelise, Thibaut's stepsister, niece of Desramé), I Conti di antichi cavalieri, ed. Alberto del Monte Cisalpino-Goliardica, 1972, pp. 118-22. The illumination at the bottom of this page, 70V, has three parts. Starting at the left, the three men travelling through Hell, Guillaume in front and frontal; Huon to his left and side view; and Aeneas barely visible behind Guillaume's right. In the middle is a lady, side view, in a fancy purple dress with gold decorations; and to the right is a crowned man on a white horse with his sword raised to strike. His trappings are all gold- spurs, saddle, bit. MS este followed by expunctuated -e: dots both below and above. Guilla[u]me: there is an abbreviation apostrophe after the two ll's, so though the name is usually spelled Guillame in the text we have added the u here. Dante, Inf.,3.103-105. This is the first part of the illumination at the foot of 71R: three men are outside a city wall, within which (center) is a knight without a head covering, but a beard and long haïr, in flames. He wears armor covered by a yellow tunic decorated with black G's. This is the second part of the illumination on 71R, to the right. Inside the city wall, devils are pushing that same figure (in yellow with black G's) into a cave opening (Hell, one presumes). Girardo au Fraite [de Vienne] is a chanson de geste character, lord of Burgundy, Milon's brother, father of Rainier, grandfather of Oliver according to the Geste Francor. He revolted against Charlemagne, refusing to aid him in Aspremont. René Louis, De l'histoire à la légende, 3 vols, Imprimerie moderne, 1946-47, proposes various theories about the multiple Girards in chansons de geste. After 'laig', letter scratched out; again looks like white-out over the spot. There are no other forms of this as noun or as adjective. However, the suffix -borg does appear, where -urg does not. "The Burgundian" is Girard, lord of Vienne, known not only for his pride but his fierce fighting against the Saracens. 'non vaut si' is written over a scratch-out. The "bone" is very hard to read because of a black smear at the top of the folio that almost completely covers it. Po[st]és: cf forms of "e[st]." T: per fare a luy dalmazo, si aveseno posanza, v. 9959. Again, cf. Dante and Virgil- Filippo Argenti? Tisiaus: Tisias is reported to have been the first theoretician of rhetoric in ancient Greece. It is taken that he was the student of one Corax, who has left no written work. Tradition has it that, after the fall of the monarchy in Sicily in the 5th c. BCE, the rise of democracy occasioned a need for persuasive speech (command no longer being accepted). One successful Sicilian practitioner was Gorgias who went to Athens in 427 BCE, where he became a major figure among the Sophists. In the Gorgias, Plato accused rhetoricians of favoring opinion over truth, success in the moment over enduring verities. (See also Phaedrus 267a-b.) Thus, in the history of rhetoric, Tisias would stand in the same relationship to rhetoric as the Sophists to sophistry. Support for this view comes in the theory that Corax was not a separate person, but that the word, which means "crow" is actually a derogatory nickname for Tisias himself. Rhetoric received a higher standing with Aristotle, fascinated with how things break down into their component parts, who wrote his Rhetoric as an analytical guide to, and practical manual for, the art—but he distinguished it from logic (dialectic). In the later Middle Ages, therefore, Tisias may be taken as a mythical founder, an archetype for all who indulge in untruth for emotional effect. Whatever his reputation in antiquity, in this passage, Berlin, lines 10324-10351, Tisias seems to represent all seven liberal arts (10328). The reference to his singing includes another of the seven: grammar, logic, rhetoric, arithmetic, geometry, astronomy, and music. Wilfred Major, Epicharmus, Tisias, and the Early History of Rhetoric, Harvard Studies in Classical Philology 107 (2013), 55-72; A. G. Hinks, "Tisias and Corax and the Invention of Rhetoric," The Classical Quarterly 34,1/2 (Jan.-Apr., 1940), 61-69. (Alan E. Bernstein). This scene may refer to the beginning of the mass; at that era, the "introit involves the singing of a Psalm, which by this period would have been sung alternatingly by two choir bodies," and that might account for the "a bis" idea. Alternatively, it may be like improvisory practice where "one singer or group of singers would sing the original chant tune, and the other voices might improvise or sing composed counterpoint above it" and "vocal polyphony was used during mass, often with a low line carrying the chant tune, and upper voices providing countermelodies, improvised or otherwise." Where and when it was done and if the celebrant was involved would be difficult to verify since the specific origin of this story is not known. We thank Remi Chiu, Assoc. Prof. of Fine Arts (Music) at LUM for his collaboration. There appears to have been a saut de même au même in an original text here, since both B and T repeat the same verb in two lines in a row. The second would be more likely "dit"/"dist" or "fait." Scure appears twice in the text; obscure or oscure in various forms, seven times. There are no forms with an a- prefix. ras: Turin has "rasy", shorn, but in OF "ras" can also mean "guilty." That however would not be immediately visible to the bystander. The construction of this line is somewhat unclear: croie is clear in the MS; in T the line is also problematic. Cf. line 420, cro ge. Under pde, above cristenté, a wormhole in the MS. Tobler 1884, p. 606 to end. A large blot on this line, from -vre a- that also goes down to the following line onto the top of the date.
